content.description: Start with two hands on the flake's undercling, follow it right and up to the top out. Extremely sharp.
content.location: Far right side of the Carbon Dyno ledge area.

content.description: Nice blank arete with good landing on the left side of the tree. Exciting topout and easily done on the right side or the left side of the arete, choose your landing zone and go. I like the right side, especially with no spotter.

Slappy powerful sloper problem.  Sit start matched on crimp, work up to big jug, up to slopers and out left along arete to a sidepull and then a horn/sloper .  Top out from here. If it feels easy, you probably topped out too soon.
content.location: On the charley sheen boulder, on your right as soon as you walk into the homeless camp proper.  This boulder is L shaped and has some huge huecos in it.

content.description: Nice slab to the right of the tree. Blank, yet well featured granite. Not as coarse as the High Voltage area. Down climb(see pic) on back side is classic and easy.
Sit Start on large diagonal, work up a couple small pinches to top and mantel out.  Sharp. Try not to beached whale too bad at the top.
content.location: On the froggy boulder.  Adjacent to the homeless boulder.  Near the dog boulder.  Sit start on large diagonal. Near fire ring up against rock.

content.description: Begin standing on the trail side face’s bulging bottom shelf. Left hand on the arete, pirouette, traverse across the shelf, solve the crux face and mantle.
Start matched on big jug and work directly up.  Beta Hint : this is a feet first problem,   if you climb it hands first    its gonna be a lot harder.
content.location: Tallest line on the lonely boulder.   Right off of the green trail on the little plateau between fern gully and homeless camp gully.    Starts right by the little pine tree, on the big edge/jug/horizontal.

content.description: Sit, climb the crack forming the seam of a dihedral. Luckily no crack technique is required. Pulling on is probably the crux. Avoid the large detached rock on top.
content.location: A portion of the cliff band behind I-95 arete, right of Jug haul.

content.description: To the left of Dubious Encounter, follow the jugs up the face.
On the backside of the slabby boulder, starts on the left side of the face and follows the obvious arete. tops out on Dispair. Slightly highball but juggy at the top.

Start standing matched on the big jug at the opening to the roof.  Work left around the corner out of the roof using the finger pocket and then small crystals on the slab face for hands and feet. a cool, complex opening move.   then work up to big flake/sidepull and work your feet out left on crystals and nubs (careful they crumble a bit )   and then work into finger pocket near the top, and on to the big blind flake/jugs for the top out.   Semi HB and classic.  Theres an option for an amazing low start to this problem down under the roof...   if youre really good.
content.location: This problem is on the south face of the brontosaurus boulder. This is the first huge boulder as you walk into homeless camp from the green trail. Problem is on the large face you first see as you walk in.  You get down via a easy reverse mantle/ downclimb on the highside of the boulder.

content.description:
Starts sitting with right hand on the arete and left hand a left-facing rail. Follow the arete up and top out. Next face to the right side is off.

 The first few moves are the hardest.
content.location: To the right of The Carbon Dyno.

content.description: On the front side of the slabby boulder you can find a crystaly rail to sit start on, go strait up to top and traverse over to the lone jug(can see in picture) and top out from here.

This is a commiting arete/traverse on fairly good rock.  There are some slopers and very sharp edges as you work left up the arete.  The problem stand starts on the right side of the obvious face and works left to the very top.  There are some nice crosses and front pointing and smearing.  Its a problem that has some nice beta for everyone, not just tall or short people.  The top out is very committing so make sure you are in the right space of mind before attempting.  The landing is very good until you commit to the top out.   Dont blow it.
content.protection: In my opinion you're gonna want at least two pads for this one.  The last slopers are marginal and if your hands skate off its a ways down.
content.location: The boulder should be easy to find if you look at the pic.  Its in the middle of the boulder field about 100 yards from the highway.  You can walk off the back of the boulder.

content.description: Starting the same as Death and work right on tiny holds and then up and right along the crystal intrusion
Starting on the slab boulder on the back left side. Work up tiny sharp crystals straight up to a good jug at the lip.

The first large boulder encountered entering ISHC.

Begin on the cheater stone, or move a ton of leaves away to find the bottom foot. Climb crystals up to the scoop and cut left to the horn. More technical than physical, find the slab wisdom.
Standing, climb the crystalline left arete, rocking over from an undercling up to a horizontal. Fire for the top.
content.protection: Perfect landing, just don’t fall off the cliff.
content.location: Edge of the cliff above/left Jug haul. Right of a cool chimney/ roped face?

content.description:
direct start to Dogs Doing Brain Surgery. Go strait up using some painful underclings/sidepulls to the same exit as the arete. 

  named after my dog decided to lay down on my pad while I was climbing.

Sit start in the dihedral on the left side of the face. Make a big move up to the crapy sharp pocket and gaston. Bust left to the jug, hold the little swing and follow up the jug line on the left side. Project: Straight up from the pocket.

Nice area to check out, all kinds of rock from TR sized cliffs to sitdown cave crack problems to a sweet warmup boulder with 3-4 V3 and under. This area looks like it had a full time resident within the last 10-20 years and is conveniently located on the side of I-95. You have probably driven past a hundred times and said "hmmm"...
